Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Navigating from Vision to Change with Bio-MAPS

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project takes major steps towards concretely defining core concepts and competencies outlined in the NSF-AAAS report, Vision and Change, and provides tools to allow programmatic assessment in undergraduate biology education. The intellectual merit of this project derives from the development, validation, and field-testing of tools called Bio-MAPS (Biology-Measuring Achievement and Progression in Science). Specifically, four Bio-MAPS assessments are being produced: molecular and cellular biology, physiology and neuroscience, ecology and evolution, and an overall comprehensive measure. The research team is working with biology faculty at diverse institutions that span the breadth of higher education to develop a framework that outlines expectations for what students should know and be able to do at different collegiate levels.

Data from Bio-MAPS are expected to provide dramatic broader impacts and catalyze curricular reform by: 1) diagnosing areas in which students struggle despite instruction, 2) allowing two-year community colleges to evaluate how well they are preparing students for transfer to four-year institutions, 3) inspiring and directing faculty and institutional conversations about enacting change at the programmatic level, 4) helping administrators focus limited resources on aspects of the curricula needing revision, and 5) challenging faculty to re-design courses to scaffold student learning. Biology departments can also use Bio-MAPS assessments to demonstrate evidence of student learning for accreditation processes.

Many agencies now require evidence of student learning and data on how well programs meet the needs of diverse student populations. This focus on tangible learning outcomes requires that institutions have a means of quantitatively measuring student progression through a curriculum. Bio-MAPS can provide a means of measuring student progress through a curriculum. Other science disciplines may be interested in developing similar assessments for their students.

This project is being funded jointly by the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Directorate of Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education as part of their efforts to support Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Program-level assessments are important tools designed to measure student learning during the course of an undergraduate major. Their creation has been propelled by a national interest in ensuring that college participation leads to measurable learning outcomes. In light of rising tuition costs, colleges and universities are facing increasing pressure to document impacts on students while accounting for incoming attributes and abilities.  Assessing students at multiple time points throughout a curriculum can motivate faculty to develop essential learning outcomes for their program and consider how students will achieve these outcomes regardless of the specific courses they take. By providing information on student understanding at key time points, program-level assessments can assist departments in determining the cumulative impact of their courses and pinpointing areas for improvement. In addition, accreditation agencies increasingly require that programs collect and respond to assessment data. 

 

Although many tools for measuring and making inferences about student learning exist in the life sciences, they primarily target student thinking at the beginning and end of a topic or single course.  Few assessments exist that can measure student progress over the course of a major or program. With this grant, we first established a framework (BioCore Guide), and then developed and published a suite of programmatic assessment instruments referred to as Bio-MAPS designed to measure student understanding of the key concepts outlined in the framework (Measuring Achievement and Progression in Science).  These assessments include the Molecular Biology Capstone Assessment, Phys-MAPS, EcoEvo-MAPS, and GenBio-MAPS. 

 

The suite of Bio-MAPS assessments are intended to measure changes in student thinking across a curriculum by testing student understanding at multiple time-points during an undergraduate program, such as when students enter the major, after the introductory biology series, and just prior to graduation. Each assessment is aligned with the core concepts of biology outlined in the Vision and Change report and further articulated in the BioCore Guide: evolution, structure function, information flow, pathways and transformations of energy and matter, and systems. Each assessment follows the same general format: question stems that present a biological scenario, followed by multiple statements, to which students answer either T/F or likely/unlikely. Through student interviews, expert feedback, pilot testing, and statistical modeling, we established evidence of validity and reliability for the assessments, such that administrators of the assessments can be confident that the instruments measure their intended constructs.  

The intellectual merit of this project is the suite of Bio-MAPS assessments themselves, in what they have revealed about student thinking, and in their potential to help programs determine how to improve their curricula to maximize student learning. For each instrument, common student incorrect ideas were identified that persist across different levels of students, while other ideas were identified that are challenging for introductory students but mastered by higher level students. Administrators of these instruments can follow cohorts of students as they progress through a major, determine the most challenging concepts, and make changes to how these concepts are taught in order to better prepare future students.       

The broader impact of the Bio-MAPS assessments is evident from the substantial interest the academic community has shown in the development and availability of these tools. Over 60 institutions nationally piloted the final versions of these instruments. Since publication, the Bio-MAPS assessments are being used widely by 2-year and 4-year institutions to routinely gather information on student progress.  In fall 2019 alone, nearly 6000 students from over 50 different institutions took one of the Bio-MAPS assessments.   


In response to the increased need, we created a website (http://cperl.lassp.cornell.edu/bio-maps) to allow instructors and students easy access to the Bio-MAPS assessments. After students complete a given assessment, instructors are automatically sent a score report that contains summary statistics such as average student performance. We have recently developed new data exploration tools where instructors can compare their data: 1) over time, 2) to a national average, and/or 3) between different demographic groups (e.g., gender, first generation status). Importantly, these data can now be used by institutions to identify any performance gaps that exist within their student populations and monitor the impact of interventions on increasing equitable outcomes for minoritized students. Taken together, Bio-MAPS assessments provide the tools necessary to encourage instructors and administrators at different institutions to explore and share common student struggles, ultimately helping programs across the country better serve their student populations.
